Released as the second expansion to the original Half-Life, Blue Shift tells the story we've come to know and love, this time from the perspective of Barney Calhoun, one of the many security guards in Black Mesa.

Being that you play as a lowly security guard, much of the game feels more stripped down and basic than the original game and even Opposing Force, an expansion which offered many different spins on the typical Half-Life arsenal and even new enemies. This time around you've only got your basic guns, a flashlight, your security gear and the same old Xen creatures to battle, which is completely fine of course, but seeing as this came a whole 2 years after Opposing Force, some people were understandably disappointed by this expansion.

There is a reason for this, however. This expansion was originally developed as an exclusive for the Dreamcast port of the game, which was later cancelled. This console exclusive expansion idea would however be brought back later that year for the release of the PlayStation 2 port with the co-op expansion Half-Life: Decay.

What Blue Shift did bring to the table (other than the solid Half-Life gameplay and storyline) was a brand-new "High-Definition Pack", which replaced old character and weapon models with newer, higher-poly ones. For the most part, this was a welcome addition, with some minor controversy from the community about some of the guns being replaced with completely different ones.

All in all, I think Blue Shift is a solid expansion, but could've done with a little variety in its presentation.

Blue Shift is a standalone add-on for the original Half-Life. It allows to experience Black Mesa events from a less heroic point of view of Barney Calhoun, a security guard. This role works really well in the beginning: Black Mesa falls apart, monsters are the main enemies, ammo is scarce, and there is struggle to survive. However, the role of a confused security guard is neglected as soon as army men come into sight. Defeating battalions of highly trained killing machines creates a sudden shift in tone. Now Barney is a victorious conquerer armed from toes to teeth and is able to overcome any obstacle with ease. Previous sense of danger evaporates. Monsters are exchanged with hitscan enemies and their dead bodies provide enough ammo to supply an army base. Original Half-Life had a good mix where it used soldiers scarcely and positioned them strategically. Blue Shift doesn't have such subtlety. It throws packs of enemies on the player. It would be better if there were few soldiers which presented great danger, with monsters and environmental hazards being the most prominent threats. 

Immersion issues aside, this add-on has solid gameplay, engaging level design and interesting enough story to rationalize shooting an interdimensional alien with a magnum revolver.
It's enjoyable experience for the ones who miss the original Half-Life, but crave for something new. I'd recommend to play it on normal difficulty.

Half-life: Blue Shift это вторая официальная модификация от Gearbox, которая нам даёт сыграть за обычного охранника.
В этой игре нам предстоит сыграть за лучшего друга, самого Гордона Фримена. Интересная задумка, которая раскрывает все стороны конфликта. В эпицентре обычный охранник, который почти беззащитен. Ни каких H.E.V. костюмов, ни каких P.C.V бронежилетов. Обычный бронежилет и каска.

Мод имеет интересную задумку, но что-то пошло не так. К сожалению, мод ничего нового не приносит в игровом плане как таковом. Мод очень короткий по сравнению с оригинальной игрой и первым официальным "модом" Half-life: Opposing Force. Слишком много "катсцен" и мало игры. Я понимаю, что игру нельзя создать без "катсцен", но перебарщивать с этим тоже нельзя. В Half-life главным был игровой процесс, "катсцены" были, но они были сделаны так, что ты их мог просто пробежать и ничего не слушать. Нет нового оружия и игровых механик, которые появились в Half-life: Opposing Force. Очень маленькие карты, которые постоянно меняются. В оригинале карты были больше. 

Я бы мог поставить оценку - не рекомендую, но не буду. Мод всё равно классный, он рассказывает о приключениях Барни Калхуна, второстепенного персонажа из игры Half-life 2, а если его не было, то и персонажа бы не было. Мод можно пройти и его больше не трогать, можно эту игру оставить для коллекции, и не играть. "Мультиплеера" нет. У нас есть примеры хуже - Half-life: Decay.

"Half-Life: Blue Shift", is the prequel to the hit movie sensation "Paul Blart: Mall Cop" starring Kevin James. Fans tend to refer to this game as "Paul Blart: Mall Cop 0" as a reference to the film. This game is relatively short, but this makes sense, considering most of the game's memory is used to store both of the Paul Blart movies, which you can watch at your own discretion. One issue is that the plot points that link the films and the game are behind a paywall. You have to buy the "Paul Blart: Mall Cop 0.5" dlc to access it. But, all in all, I had fun with this adventure with our favorite mall cop, and I would recommend it to all. I give this one a 5/5.

Blue Shift is just more Half-Life. It's still decent, but really short.

It's hard to not make comparisons with the preceding Half-Life expansion, Opposing Force, which makes this one feel far smaller in several ways.

The campaign only lasts about 3 hours and there's no multiplayer whatsoever.

The gameplay is largely unchanged from the original Half-Life, except that instead of using HEV stations to restore your armor, you have to pick up guard vests and helmets from dead security guards.

While I consider this expansion to be decent, it doesn't really bring anything different to the table. If you're a huge Half-Life fan and/or the game's on sale, knock yourself out, but otherwise you might want to look for something else.

Paradoxically both the shorter and more monologue-heavy of the Half-Life expansions. In contrast to Opposing Force, this adds nothing to the Half-Life universe. Unless the base game and other expansion didn't quite scratch your itch for classic FPS action, it's worth a skip.
